iti48:4.1: Kāsāvakaṇṭhā is usually taken as “ochre-necks” with kaṇṭha in the sense “throat”, but the commentary is not so clear: “It seems that, having tied a single ochre scrap (khaṇḍa) around their hand or neck (gīvā) they wander about.” Thus while the commentary mentions the neck, it directly glosses kaṇṭha with khaṇḍa, a term for a scrap or portion; eg. a cammakhaṇḍa is an item made from scraps of leather (Bu Pc 15:2.1.8). Khaṇḍa is doubly appropriate, since it is a common word for “broken” precepts.
